scene.name: intro
scene.line: That's important. Most of our product goes out at night. You never know who you'll run into in the daylight, and dusk can be treacherously misleading with all that indirect light. `The magic hour`, eh?
scene.option: Drivers sleep in the day, then?

scene.name: magic-hour
scene.line: `(To CONWAY.)` The angle of the sun at dusk and dawn means the light is mostly indirect reflections from the sky. Everything looks like a movie, it's all a bit softer.
scene.option: Drivers sleep in the day, then?
`Conway had to get off the highway `—` too loud, too murky.`

scene.name: sleep-day
scene.line: Sure, those that sleep. Miguel pulled extra day shifts when he could. Sometimes he'd help me, you know. Sometimes over in bottling.
He shouldn't have been out driving at dusk. Weird shadows. Soft light. Dangerous.
scene.option: `Conway had to get off the highway `—` too loud, too murky.`

scene.name: dusk-vignette
scene.line: `He turned off into some gray cornfield, in Indiana.`

scene.name: empties
scene.line: `He kept them over there so the smell wouldn't spread. That window was always open a crack.`

scene.name: pull-over
scene.option: `He just needed a nap, even if he ran late.`

scene.name: birds
scene.line: `Seeing those migrations close up, they looked random. He thought about the load in the trailer `—` thousands of plastic cups. Somebody wanted those cups in Rockford that night.`

scene.name: nap
scene.line: `He was only human. He'd been out since the headlights were on `—` didn't even stop for coffee. He cracked a beer at three, eyes on the road. Half past four, he dodged some stray cattle.`
`The headlights were coming back on. Rockford could wait. Early morning couldn't be much worse than late night, what could they care?`
